quotes.text: If you say, "Do you have any feedback for me?" You're wasting your breath.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A blunt, counterintuitive reframing that highlights why generic feedback requests usually fail in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The question that I like to ask is, "What could I do or stop doing that would make it easier to work with me?"
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, behavior-focused prompt that makes it easier for others to give specific, actionable feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Do not write down my question because if you sound like Kim Scott and not like yourself, then other people are not going to believe you want the answer.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Emphasizes authenticity as a key mechanism for eliciting honest feedback rather than performative responses.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It needs to sound authentic to you, and if everybody can write down their question, who they're going to ask it of and then pop it into their calendar right now, this will be one of the most productive podcasts in all of podcast land.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Turns the idea into an immediate implementation plan (write it, choose a person, schedule it) to drive real behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Defining Radical Candor and the 2x2
quotes.text: Radical Candor is just what happens when you care personally and challenge directly at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Defines the core Radical Candor mental model as the intersection of two behaviors leaders can deliberately practice.

quotes.topic_title: Defining Radical Candor and the 2x2
quotes.text: So you can think about it as a two by two framework. On the vertical axis is care personally, the horizontal axis is challenge directly.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Gives a simple 2x2 diagnostic tool practitioners can use to categorize feedback behaviors and adjust in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Defining Radical Candor and the 2x2
quotes.text: If I'm a jerk to you Lenny, then I'm going to send you into fight or flight mode and then you literally cannot hear what I'm saying, so I'm wasting my breath.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Explains a practical mechanism for why harsh delivery fails—people physiologically stop processing the message—making it actionable to change approach.

quotes.topic_title: Defining Radical Candor and the 2x2
quotes.text: By far and away the most common problem occurs when we do remember to show that we care personally because you know what? Most people try to be nice people. So we do remember to show that we care personally, but we're so worried about not hurting someone's feelings or not offending them, that we fail to tell them something they'd be better off knowing in the long run. And that is what I call ruinous empathy.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive trap that “being nice” can be harmful when it suppresses necessary candor, naming it as a distinct failure mode.

quotes.topic_title: Defining Radical Candor and the 2x2
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean, I would say 90% of us make 90% of our mistakes in that ruinous empathy bucket.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Provides a memorable quantitative heuristic that emphasizes where most teams should focus their improvement efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Why Radical Candor matters: Kim’s “um” story
quotes.text: She cared personally and she challenged directly.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Captures the core Radical Candor framework as two simultaneous behaviors leaders can practice.

quotes.topic_title: Why Radical Candor matters: Kim’s “um” story
quotes.text: When you say um every third word, it makes you sound stupid.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A concrete example of direct challenge that cuts through defensiveness and prompts behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Why Radical Candor matters: Kim’s “um” story
quotes.text: some people might say it was mean of her to say I sounded stupid, but in fact, it was the kindest thing that she could have done for me at that moment in my career
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Reframes blunt feedback as an act of care when it prevents long-term career harm.

quotes.topic_title: Why Radical Candor matters: Kim’s “um” story
quotes.text: relationships don't scale. But she did do those things for her direct reports and the people who she worked most closely with, all of us.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A practical leadership constraint: focus deep care on the relationships you can actually maintain.

quotes.topic_title: Why Radical Candor matters: Kim’s “um” story
quotes.text: And even though relationships don't scale, culture does scale.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how individual care can propagate through an organization via culture.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical guidance: HIP + CORE feedback framework
quotes.text: So anyway, I think that the important thing for these conversations, these sort of two-minute impromptu moments of management, is to go into the conversation being humble.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Sets the tone for effective real-time feedback by emphasizing humility as the starting condition.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical guidance: HIP + CORE feedback framework
quotes.text: So to me, candor implies here's how I understand the situation. I'm also curious to know how you understand the conversation.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Reframes feedback as a dialogue rather than a one-way “truth,” making it easier to deliver and receive.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical guidance: HIP + CORE feedback framework
quotes.text: But usually if I'm telling myself and Lenny, you can tell me if you have the same problem, but if I tell myself, Oh, I'm going to wait for a better moment to tell this person this thing, what I'm really saying is I'm never going to say.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A practical mental model for why “waiting for the right time” often becomes avoidance, pushing toward immediacy.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical guidance: HIP + CORE feedback framework
quotes.text: Now I say have these conversations synchronously and I'm going to recommend phone over video.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Counterintuitive channel guidance that challenges the default assumption that video is best for sensitive feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical guidance: HIP + CORE feedback framework
quotes.text: I think it's really important to remember that for both praise and criticism, you want to use sort of context, observation, result, next step.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Introduces the CORE structure as a repeatable method to make feedback specific, behavioral, and actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Ruinous empathy story: avoiding hard truths hurts everyone
quotes.text: Because ruinous empathy creates this false harmony, which is really bad.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Names the core failure mode: avoiding hard truths feels kind but actually produces harmful “false harmony.”

quotes.topic_title: Ruinous empathy story: avoiding hard truths hurts everyone
quotes.text: So the part of me that was worried about my reputation as a leader, that was the manipulative insincerity part, the part of me that was worried about Bob's feelings, that was the ruinous empathy part.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A clear diagnostic split between two common motives for sugarcoating feedback—self-protection vs. sparing feelings.

quotes.topic_title: Ruinous empathy story: avoiding hard truths hurts everyone
quotes.text: I realized that if I didn't fire Bob, I was going to lose all my best performers because not only had it been unfair to Bob not to tell him, I also had been unfair to everyone on the team.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Shows the compounding team-level cost of delayed feedback: it harms both the struggling person and top performers.

quotes.topic_title: Ruinous empathy story: avoiding hard truths hurts everyone
quotes.text: He looked me right in the eye and he said, "Why didn't you tell me?"
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A memorable moment that underscores how “being nice” by withholding feedback can feel like betrayal to the recipient.

quotes.topic_title: Ruinous empathy story: avoiding hard truths hurts everyone
quotes.text: You should be helping this person to improve. This person deserves to have a job where they can excel and you either help them excel on this team or you help them find a different job where they can excel, because everyone can do great work somewhere.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Actionable leadership principle: candid feedback is an obligation to help someone succeed—here or elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: People-pleasing, bias, and giving earlier feedback
quotes.text: realizing that my job was not to be liked. My job was to care about other people and to get out of my own head and to become others focused is what helped me kind of let go of the need to be liked.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A practical reframing for leaders: prioritize care and outcomes over being liked to unlock candor.

quotes.topic_title: People-pleasing, bias, and giving earlier feedback
quotes.text: the sort of likability- competence bias that a lot of women face pushed me, especially early in my career, in the wrong direction on challenge directly.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Names a specific bias that can systematically discourage direct feedback, especially for women leaders.

quotes.topic_title: People-pleasing, bias, and giving earlier feedback
quotes.text: "Bob, maybe I'm misinterpreting the expression on your face, but it looks to me like you are not happy with this. What's going on?"
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A diagnostic-question technique that invites self-assessment while signaling humility about reading body language.

quotes.topic_title: People-pleasing, bias, and giving earlier feedback
quotes.text: I would have not been shy about pointing out very specifically every problem that I saw in that piece of work, every single one.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A concrete method for making feedback land: be exhaustive and specific rather than vague about “a number of mistakes.”

quotes.topic_title: People-pleasing, bias, and giving earlier feedback
quotes.text: I think my fear around his tears was probably more about my fear than what was actually likely to happen. But I think we do fear someone else getting upset more often than they actually get upset. We have kind of a negativity bias when it comes to part of the reason why we're reluctant to give feedback.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A counterintuitive explanation for avoidance: leaders overestimate emotional fallout due to negativity bias.

quotes.topic_title: Career conversations as a way to show care
quotes.text: I actually did that and I learned this from a manager of mine is just almost work backwards from ask them, what do you want to achieve in your career? Where do you want to go in this company and make sure they know you know what they want, and then basically work backwards from to get there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical coaching method: start with the employee’s destination and reverse-engineer the path and feedback from there.

quotes.topic_title: Career conversations as a way to show care
quotes.text: I think one of the really important things that all managers can do for their direct reports to show that they care is to have real meaningful career conversations, where you talk about their life story, sort of their past, whatever part of it they're comfortable talking to you about so that you understand what motivates them at work.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Reframes “showing care” as understanding a person’s motivations through structured, personal career conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Career conversations as a way to show care
quotes.text: And I would have three separate 45 minute conversations, so one about their past, one about their future, their dreams for the future, and it's not just the next couple of years. It's like imagine at the height of your career you have everything you want. What does it look like? And give me three or four different pictures of that because very few of us know what we want to do when we grow up.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable framework (three 45-minute conversations) that pushes beyond short-term planning into multiple long-term “future pictures.”

quotes.topic_title: Career conversations as a way to show care
quotes.text: Then the third conversation is to sort of sit down with your director report and come up with a career action plan. So given what motivates you and where you want to go, what are the skills that it would be useful for you to develop so that you can get where you want to go and who can I introduce you to? What are the educational opportunities? Can we tweak your job so that you're gaining those skills so you're at least taking a step in the direction of your dreams, even if you're not there yet?
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Turns career talk into execution by mapping motivations to skills, introductions, learning options, and job design tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing candor in a ruinous-empathy culture
quotes.text: There's really an order of operations to radical candor, and if you begin with soliciting criticism, then you take the first and most important step to improving your relationship with that person enough that it becomes easier for you to give it as well as to get it.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Introduces a practical sequence: build trust by asking for feedback first, which then makes giving feedback easier and safer.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing candor in a ruinous-empathy culture
quotes.text: So if you say, "Do you have any feedback for me?" You're wasting your breath. The other person's going to say, "Oh no, everything's fine."
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Challenges the common approach to soliciting feedback by explaining why generic asks fail in real workplaces.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing candor in a ruinous-empathy culture
quotes.text: The question that I like to ask is, "What could I do or stop doing that would make it easier to work with me?" But do not write down my question because if you sound like Kim Scott and not like yourself, then other people are not going to believe you want the answer. It needs to sound authentic to you.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Gives a high-signal feedback prompt while warning that authenticity (not scripts) is key to getting honest answers.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing candor in a ruinous-empathy culture
quotes.text: I was working with Christa Quarles when she was CEO of OpenTable and she said, "Kim, I could never imagine those words coming out of my mouth." She said, "The way I like to ask is tell me why I'm wrong."
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of adapting the feedback-ask to fit a leader’s voice and style.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing candor in a ruinous-empathy culture
quotes.text: Being authentic does not mean ignoring the impact you're having on others.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A memorable principle for balancing authenticity with empathy when choosing how to ask for criticism.

quotes.topic_title: How to solicit feedback weekly and make it routine
quotes.text: Well, I think if you are a manager, you need to be soliciting every week feedback from each of your direct reports, and you need to sort of, I would budget five minutes at the end of your one-on-one to solicit feedback.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A concrete weekly cadence and time-box (5 minutes) that makes feedback solicitation routine and scalable.

quotes.topic_title: How to solicit feedback weekly and make it routine
quotes.text: And you also want to ask that go-to question of your cross-functional peers who you work most closely with and of your boss. And I think you don't want to ask the same question every single time. It'll start to sound like you don't really want the answer, but you want to make this part of your daily weekly routine with the people who you interact most closely with.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: Extends feedback beyond direct reports and adds the tactic of varying prompts to keep requests authentic.

quotes.topic_title: How to solicit feedback weekly and make it routine
quotes.text: Never,
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A hard-line standard: don’t accept “everything’s fine,” which forces real feedback rather than polite avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: How to solicit feedback weekly and make it routine
quotes.text: There's no such thing as emotional Novocaine. That's why I don't believe in scripts.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes feedback discomfort as unavoidable—so you must manage it, not “wordsmith” it away.

quotes.topic_title: How to solicit feedback weekly and make it routine
quotes.text: Simplest way to embrace the discomfort is to close your mouth and count to six.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A practical micro-technique for creating silence so the other person can actually answer a hard feedback question.

quotes.topic_title: Handling discomfort, defensiveness, and rewarding candor
quotes.text: There's no such thing as emotional Novocaine. That's why I don't believe in scripts. People believe if I just say the magic words like the door will open, that's not how it works. It's a give and take. So you want to sort of be prepared to embrace that discomfort. The only way out is through. Simplest way to embrace the discomfort is to close your mouth and count to six.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive reminder that no phrasing eliminates discomfort—so the practical move is to embrace silence to create space for candor.

quotes.topic_title: Handling discomfort, defensiveness, and rewarding candor
quotes.text: The third step is to make sure that you listen with the intent to understand not to respond, because you're probably going to feel defensive and that's okay. It doesn't mean you're a lesser mortal or that you're shut down the feedback. All it means is that you're human. And that's all part of this. You want to figure out how to manage your natural defensive reaction to critical feedback, which you're probably going to have. The simplest tactic I can offer folks there is to think of some follow-up questions.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A practical framework for handling defensiveness: normalize it, then redirect energy into follow-up questions to understand rather than rebut.

quotes.topic_title: Handling discomfort, defensiveness, and rewarding candor
quotes.text: A person takes a huge risk, especially if this person is your employee. A person takes a huge risk to give you critical feedback. And if you do not reward that risk richly, you're never going to get any feedback again.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A clear incentive model for feedback culture: candor is a risk-taking behavior that must be rewarded or it disappears.

quotes.topic_title: Handling discomfort, defensiveness, and rewarding candor
quotes.text: And so what you want to do is you want to look for that five or 10% of whatever the person said that you can agree with, and you want to give voice to that. And then what you want to do is you want to say, "As for the rest of it, I want to think about it and get back to you." And then you've got to get back to them. You got to offer a respectful explanation of why you disagree. And it's tempting to feel like a disagreement poses a risk to our relationships, but it's not disagreement that poses a risk to our relationships. It's unspoken disagreement.
quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.context: A concrete method for disagreeing without shutting people down: validate the 5–10% you share, commit to follow up, and avoid the real relationship killer—unspoken disagreement.
